column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0038] FIG. 2 shows the assembly of the mechanism that transports the cassette holder 7 into and out of the device.
#Text=A base 10 having a slot 11 supports a spring plate 12 having a slot 13.

#Text=Two shoulder screws 14 engage the slots (11 and 13) from bottom and top respectively in the base 10 and the spring plate 12 for the purpose of guiding the spring plate 12 in a linear motion when the cassette holder 7 is inserted into the device.

#Text=A pocket 15 in the base houses a spring 16 and a damper means 17 that together, propel the spring plate 12, and therefore the cassette holder 7 in a direction opposite to its direction of insertion, at a controlled rate that is readable by the optics and logic circuitry.
#Text=An encoder strip 18 is attached to the spring plate 12 by means of a clamp 30, and is read by the encoder 19 as the spring plate 12 moves.
#Text=Encoder 19 may be, for example, a model EM1-0-250 available from U.S.
#Text=Digital of Vancouver, Wash., USA.

#Text=A barcode reader means 20 is recessed into the base 10 next to the damper means and is used to identify each test cassette 8 by reading a unique bar code label that has been placed on the bottom surface of the test cassette 8.
#Text=An open slot in the cassette holder 7 beneath the test cassette 8 allows the barcode reader means 20 an optical path to the barcode on the bottom of the test cassette 8.

#Text=[0039] FIG. 3 shows the assembly of the internal components of the device mounted onto the base 10 along with guides 21 and 22 that control the path of the cassette holder 7 as it travels into and out of the device.
#Text=The cassette holder is positioned as it would be just before entering the reader.
#Text=The housing in this embodiment is made up of separate plastic plates and comprises four walls and a cover that are held together using screws.
#Text=A back wall 23 and blank side wall 24 serve only to provide structure and to omit light from the device.
#Text=A cover 25 contains a display 26 to indicate whether a test is positive, negative or invalid.
#Text=A front wall 27 having cutout 28 allows for the entry of the cassette holder 7 while keeping ambient light from interfering with the readings of the device.
#Text=A connector and switch wall 29 contains cutouts to accept power and data connections as well as switches to activate the device and the backlight of the display 26.

#Text=[0040] The example device is used by switching on the power and inserting a test cassette 8 into the cassette holder 7 and in turn inserting the cassette holder 7 into the cutout 28 of the front wall 27 and pushing the cassette holder into the device.
#Text=As the test cassette 8 passes over the barcode reader means 20, the barcode containing an identifier on the bottom of the test cassette is read and the identifier is recorded in memory.

#Text=Once the cassette holder 7 has been pushed into the device as far as it will travel, the cassette holder 7 is released by the user and the spring 16 propels it, via the spring plate 12 in the opposite direction at a speed that is controlled by the damper 17.

#Text=This motion causes the test strip within the test cassette 8 to pass beneath a lens 4 in the optics block 3 causing any indicating stripes on the test strip to be projected onto the photo-detectors 2 on the circuit board.

#Text=During this process, the encoder strip 18 is passing through the encoder 19 and causing pulsed signals to be sent to the processor every time the spring plate 12 has progressed one encoder increment (for example, one thousandth of an inch in the example embodiment).
#Text=Upon each encoder pulse, the processor interrogates the photo-detectors 2 and enters a value into memory for both the test cassette 8 and the reference cassette 9.
#Text=[0041] FIGS. 4A through 4D show a schematic diagram of the electronic circuit of the device, in accordance with an example embodiment of the invention.
#Text=In this example, operation of the reader is controlled by a model PIC18F6527 microcontroller available from Microchip Technology, Inc., of Chandler, Ariz., USA.
#Text=Of course, any other suitable microcontroller or microprocessor system may be used.
#Text=[0042] FIG. 5 shows an optical path for a strip reader in accordance with another example embodiment of the invention.
#Text=In the configuration of FIG. 5, no reference strip is needed.
#Text=A light source 501 illuminates a strip under test 502.
#Text=In the example shown, light source 501 is a light emitting diode, but other kinds of light sources may be used.
#Text=At least some of the light reflected from strip 502 passes through lens system 503.
#Text=In this example, lens system 503 comprises two plano-convex lens elements made of glass, plastic, or other suitable material.
#Text=Other lens arrangements may be used having different numbers or kinds of elements.
#Text=For example, the simple ball lenses shown in the embodiment of FIG. 1 may be used in this embodiment as well.
